A passenger train or passenger railcar, also known as an passenger coach or passenger carriage, is a piece of railway rolling stock that is designed to carry passengers.

A passenger train is a form of rail transport that carries passengers. The term passenger train can also refer to a train which offers not just passenger transport but also goods transport, for example, a mixed train.

A steam locomotive is a type of railway locomotive that produces its pulling power through a steam engine. These locomotives are fueled by burning combustible material – usually coal, wood, or oil – to produce steam in a boiler. The steam moves reciprocating pistons which are mechanically connected to the locomotive's main wheels (drivers). Both fuel and water supplies are carried with the locomotive, either on the locomotive itself or in wagons (tenders) pulled behind.
The yellow train is a high-speed train.

The train is an old yellow train.

An electric multiple unit or EMU is a multiple unit train consisting of self-propelled carriages, using electricity as the motive power. An EMU requires no separate locomotive, as electric traction motors are incorporated within one or a number of the carriages.
The first passenger railway, the Liverpool and Manchester Railway, opened in 1830.
The Orient Express was a long-distance passenger train service created in 1883 by Compagnie Internationale des Wagons-Lits.
